title: Rachel Weisz has been cast as Elizabeth Taylor in biopic focusing on the star's AIDS charity work
text:
Well before the dawn of the 24-hour news cycle, there was one Hollywood star who commanded such unparalleled attention and gossip that she could be considered well ahead of her time.

And Elizabeth Taylor, wife to seven different men and three-time Academy Award-winning actress of Who's Afraid Of Virginia Woolf and Cleopatra fame, took on a totally different role later in life that was also extremely notable: tireless humanitarian and advocate for those afflicted with HIV and AIDS.

Now, another Oscar-winner has been cast to portray Liz in a new film that will document her activism around awareness and prevention of the disease at a time when many in the public sphere still kept a marked distance from it.

Rachel Weisz, 49, will be portraying the late movie star in the upcoming biopic A Special Relationship, Variety reports.

Filling some iconic shoes: Oscar winner Rachel Weisz has been cast as Elizabeth Taylor in a new biopic focusing on the latter's work on behalf of those afflicted with HIV/AIDS; seen here at the British Academy Film Awards in London in February

The film will focus on Taylor’s work advocating for HIV/AIDS awareness, and is based on hours of interviews and conversations with those who knew her well.

It will also highlight her close friendship with personal assistant Roger Wall, a southern gay man.

While Taylor died in 2011, she began her work around the cause as early as 1985, after her friend and costar Rock Hudson succumbed to the disease.

Legend: Elizabeth Taylor, three-time Academy Award-winning actress, took on a totally different role later in life that was also notable: tireless humanitarian and AIDS awareness advocate; seen here in 1994 at a press conference for the Elizabeth Taylor Aids Foundation

Liz's charity work around AIDS research and awareness swiftly grew in strength and breadth: in 1985, she helped found amFAR, The Foundation for AIDS Research, which remains to this day one of the leading organizations dedicated to eradicating the disease.

She also created the Elizabeth Taylor AIDS Foundation in 1991, to further her efforts to focus on care and education about AIDS prevention.

Taylor was awarded her third Oscar in 1993, which came in the form of the Jean Hersholt Humanitarian Award that was in recognition of her AIDS charity work.

'Audiences are clearly fascinated by the private lives of iconic Hollywood stars,' A Special Relationship producers Iain Canning and Emile Sherman said in a statement.

‹ Slide me › Ladies in red: The raven-haired Weisz, who was born in London just like Liz, landed the surely coveted role

'There is no one more iconic than Elizabeth Taylor, and Simon Beaufoy [Oscar-winning writer of Slumdog Millionaire] has written a role that shines a light on Elizabeth’s humor and humanity, which will be beautifully brought to life through the extraordinary talents of Rachel Weisz.'

Rachel, however, won't be the first actress to portray the violet-eyed star of Cat On A Hot Tin Roof.

In 2012, Lindsay Lohan took on the role, in a Lifetime TV movie called Liz & Dick.

Outside of A Special Relationship, Weisz is also in the midst of working on another high profile project: Black Widow, a Marvel prequel movie that will explore the origin of Scarlett Johansson's eponymous character aka Natasha Romanoff.

Activist: While Taylor died in 2011, she began her work around the cause as early as 1985, after her friend and costar Rock Hudson succumbed to the disease; seen here at the Cannes 2002 - amfAR's Cinema Against AIDS Gala

Celebrated actress in her own right: Weisz was awarded her own Oscar, for Best Supporting Actress, in 2006 for The Constant Gardener, and was nominated for the same trophy earlier this year for The Favourite
